The Risk Core Unit has provided an overview of potential market effects and risks involved for MakerDAO. The analysis is available below:     Merge Risks and Market Impacts Research       With the merge drawing closer and increased discussion about potential network fork(s), risk CU wanted to share an overview of the possible market effects and risks involved.   Background Ethereum is planning to merge the proof of stake (POS) validation mechanism with the execution layer and eliminate proof of work (POW) mining. This upgrade from POW to POS is the result of years of development effort and has strong support throughout the Ethereum and defi community. Technical execution risks ar…     After some discussion, we realized that lending markets such as Aave and Compound face greater risks. Most tokens, excluding ETH, will likely be worthless on an ETHPoW chain. Hence, one strategy users may employ to maximize their cryptoasset holdings, will likely be to borrow as much ETH as possible, collateralized mainly by stablecoins or other tokens. This will allow them to retain the potential value of a forked ETH token. Due to the fact that Aave and Compound make up a significant market share of DeFi lending, the Risk Core Unit believes that the risks are systemic and can likely impact the whole DeFi industry, including MakerDAO. content.content: This post summarises the tasks, work, and activities of the @Risk-Core-Unit for the month of February. Our primary focus this month is outlined below. A statement regarding the ongoing discussion and work of a B.Protocol integration was posted to the forum. In our opinion, the integration should be put on hold for the time being. This might be reconsidered in the future if and when B.Protocol can demonstrate higher demand for DAI locked in the B.AMM. In our opinion, at the present time, it would be more fruitful for MakerDAO to focus on opportunities such as L2 developments and D3M type modules. A second article, Maker Capital at Risk: Model Methodology, was posted to Block Analitica’s Medium page. A deeper dive into the Collateral Risk Model is set out in the paper. The Risk Core Unit uses this model to determine two key risk parameters in Maker governance: Risk Premium and Debt Ceiling. A proposal was posted to the Compound governance forum on February 9. The objective was to gauge the sentiment for reducing the cMKR borrow limit (currently set to 25,000 MKR). The availability of borrowable MKR tokens significantly reduces the cost of an Emergency Shutdown attack. Hence, reducing the MKR borrow limit on Compound should make it harder for a malicious actor to perform such an attack. The winning option was “Reduce MKR borrow cap to 5,000 MKR”. Following the recent signal request regarding FLAP auctions, the Protocol Engineering Core Unit (PE) has introduced a new solution that can limit the amount of parallel running flap-auctions. Part of this solution is a new parameter called lid. This limits the total value of DAI allowed to be sent out to auctions at any one time. The Risk Core Unit posted an analysis and parameter proposal for an appropriate lid value. The analysis reviewed historical FLAP auctions in order to gain an understanding of how competitive the surplus auction keeper ecosystem really is. This resulted in a proposed lid parameter value of 150.000 DAI. With this lid value, a maximum of 5 surplus auctions every 30 minutes, or 7.2m DAI per day, can be executed. Several updates and improvements to the MakerDAO Risk Dashboard were undertaken, such as (i) a new Auctions simulation, (ii) updates to the Compound monitor page, and (iii) improvements to the vaults debt at risk graph. More information about these updates is set out below. Following MIP40c3-SP56, we have now officially joined forces with Makerburn. This means, among other things, that Makerburn updates will be included as a separate section in the Risk Core Unit’s “month in review”. More on these updates are set out below. Key topics for February include (i) DAI on L2, (ii) Collateral Parameter pages, and (iii) a Makerburnbot integration. Two Risk Core Unit members, @Primoz and @monet-supply, are part of the MakerDAO Open Market Committee. Two changes were proposed for the month of February. content.content: Symbolic execution is, in general, a powerful tool for analyzing smart contract behavior for important properties. Utilizing Rust as the source language means that we can integrate it with Foundry, the new smart contract framework developed by Paradigm & gaining rapid adoption. This particular symbolic evm is also more modular than others that exist; often, only certain parts of a program are executed symbolically, and that choice depends on the specific analysis one is doing. This symbolic evm is modular enough that it will support various degrees of symbolic analysis as well as easily configuring which aspects are symbolic vs concrete. This will also improve performance since it means that engineers can tune which aspects are symbolic according to the particular properties they’re testing for in a given situation.

discourse_list.title: The Risk Core Unit 2022 Year in Review

content.content: This post summarises the tasks, work, and activities of the @Risk-Core-Unit for the year 2022. Included in this summary are updates highlighted in previous monthly reviews. To read previous summaries in further detail, refer to the Risk Core Unit Month in Review series.  Collateral-Related Work At the end of 2021, led by the @collateral-core-unit, several MakerDAO Core Units undertook a new coordination initiative for both on-chain and off-chain collateral. The initiative included weekly management meetings and monthly strategic planning calls between stakeholders. The sections below describe the @Risk-Core-Unit’s work in relation to this initiative for 2022.  Collateral Management With the @collateral-core-unit at the helm, throughout the course of the year, strategies and tools were developed to aid the process of aligning all the relevant stakeholders working with Maker collateral. The Collateral Status Index (CSI) spreadsheet, for example, was developed to help provide a comprehensive overview of the collateral onboarding, offboarding and management process. In addition, other procedures and documents were created to help facilitate the MIP6 process (note that MIP6 was deprecated following the Ratification Poll for Endgame Prelaunch MIP Set in October 2022). A document outlining MIP6 Recommended Guideline Metrics for Onchain Collateral Onboarding was posted to the forum in April 2022. Even though the MIP6 process is now removed, this document is still relevant and will provide context for future decision-making strategies related to collateral onboarding. Other posts were produced by the @Risk-Core-Unit in relation to the collateral stakeholder alignment initiative. A partial list is available below. Other relevant posts are available in the section “Proposals & Signal Requests”.  Statement regarding B.Protocol v2 and Maker integration and risk considerations (Feb 2022) [CurveLP-stETH-ETH] Parameters Adjustment (Mar 2022) COMP Reward Change: Impact Analysis (Apr 8, 2022) Introduction & Risk Parameters for wstETH-C Vault (Apr 18, 2022) Immediate & Short-term Parameter Changes Proposal for CRVV1ETHSTETH-A - DC and gap increase (Apr 2022)   Collateral Onboarding Risk Evaluations In total, 5 collateral onboarding risk evaluations were produced in 2022.  Compound D3M Risk Assessment (Jan 12, 2022) [PAXG] Collateral Onboarding Risk Evaluation Update (Apr 14, 2022) [rETH] Collateral Onboarding Risk Evaluation (May 20, 2022) [rETH] Collateral Onboarding Risk Evaluation Update (Sep 23, 2022) [GNO] Collateral Onboarding Risk Evaluation (Nov 16, 2022)   Collateral Liquidations & Collateral Offboarding The list below includes offboarding and auction activation proposals produced by the @Risk-Core-Unit in 2022.  Proposed parameters for offboarding TUSD-A (March 2022) [Signal Request] Offboard UNI, UNIV2DAIETH, UNIV2WBTCETH, UNIV2UNIETH, and UNIV2WBTCDAI (May 2022) [renBTC-A] Proposed Offboarding Parameters & Context (Nov 2022) [USDC-A, USDP-A, GUSD-A] Liquidation parameters & Auctions activation (Nov 2022)   Research Initiatives  Maker Risk Model Research Several posts were published to the Block Analitica Medium page and the Maker forum that explain in detail the underlying models of the Maker Risk Dashboard.  Introducing Maker Risk Dashboard (Jan 28, 2022) Maker Capital at Risk: Model Methodology (Feb 24, 2022) Maker Collateral Risk Model: Feature Analysis (Apr 26, 2022) Vault Protection Score - Model Validation (June 6, 2022) Maker Vault Liquidation ML Model (September 2, 2022) Monitoring and Mitigation of Economic Risk - From DeFi tools and processes to on-chain proposals (Nov 24, 2022)   Parameter Impact and Vault User Research The @Risk-Core-Unit performs ongoing research in several areas that relate to the risk profile of the Maker Protocol. The list below includes posts on parameter impact analyses and vault user research produced in 2022.  Impact Analysis: Lowering stETH-B Stability Fee to 0% (Sep 28, 2022) Maker Parameter Impact Analysis (October 17, 2022) Vault User Research: Intra-Protocol Exposure Migration (October 20, 2022) Vault User Research: Survival Analysis (Nov 8, 2022)   Maker Auctions Research A new iteration of the Maker auction system was introduced in May 2021. Although the auction parameters at that time were satisfactory, the @Risk-Core-Unit believed that there was still room for improvement. As a result, the @Risk-Core-Unit, in September 2022, performed an in-depth auction analysis and proposed a set of adjustments to Maker’s auction parameters for 14 different collateral types.  Collateral Auctions: Analysis & Parameter (Sep 2022)   Product Discussions Several product discussions, with ideas of how to improve certain parts of the Maker Protocol, were released throughout 2022.  Product Discussion: NFTs as MakerDAO Collateral (Jan 2022) stkMKR: Maker Staking and Tokenomics Revision (March 2022) [Informal Poll] Curve Basepool Composition (May 2022) Thoughts on Multichain DAI Liquidity Strategy (June 27, 2022)   Proposals & Signal Requests The year 2022 bore the stamp of volatile market conditions and an overall decline in the market capitalisation of the cryptoasset ecosystem. However, it was also the year of the Ethereum Merge – a highly anticipated event and technological advance that took years of research, development, and coordination. As a result, from a risk perspective, several reactionary proposals and ad-hoc decisions have been necessary to ensure the resilience and robustness of the Maker Protocol. The section below summarises the work produced by the @Risk-Core-Unit in this regard.  Flappy Friday On January 22, 2022, major liquidation events occurred as a result of a significant, sudden market downtrend. This led MakerDAO’s surplus buffer to exceed the Maximum System Surplus parameter. In turn, multiple surplus auctions (FLAP) were triggered. The surplus auction (FLAP) inefficiency of this event led to the day being referred to as “Flappy Friday”. This was one of the largest auction events in MakerDAO history and a severe stress test on the system. In response, the @Risk-Core-Unit performed a post-mortem of Flappy Friday to identify relevant insights and learnings. The analysis was used to help form an urgent signal request to stop MKR burning. It was proposed to temporarily prevent surplus auctions until the auction mechanisms could be improved. The proposed changes were (i) disabling the existing System Surplus Buffer lerp function, and (ii) setting the System Surplus Buffer parameter to 250 million DAI. Later in February 2022, the @Risk-Core-Unit posted an additional analysis and proposal regarding surplus auctions. Based on Derek’s post and the supportive outcome of the Introduce Rate Limiter into Flapper poll, the @Risk-Core-Unit proposed a key parameter for the Rate Limiter called lid – the total value of DAI allowed to be sent out to a surplus auction at once. A lid parameter value of 150.000 DAI was proposed. The lid parameter was later in May 2022 changed to 30.000 DAI, effectively reducing the number of parallel flap auctions from five to one.  Flappy Friday - CLIP and FLAP Analysis (Jan 2022) Rate Limiter Parameter Proposal (Feb 2022)   The Ethereum PoS Merge On September 15, 2022, the Ethereum network transitioned from Proof-of-Work (PoW) to Proof-of-Stake (PoS). In August 2022, as the Ethereum Merge was drawing closer, there was a lot of discussion about potential network fork(s) that could happen as a result of the merge. In response, the @Risk-Core-Unit produced an overview of the possible market effects and risks involved. The situation was continuously monitored up until the merge. Two respective analyses and proposals were also provided to Compound and Aave, since lending markets were especially vulnerable to potential forks, and since they constitute a systemic level of market share in DeFi. Both proposals were adopted, which resulted in the payment of 100 COMP from Compound, and 60 AAVE from Aave, to the MCD Pause Proxy contract. Further details below.  Maker – Merge Risks and Market Impacts – Original Post (Aug 2022) Maker – Merge Risks and Market Impacts – Update 1 (Aug 2022) Maker – Merge Risks and Market Impacts – Update 2 (Aug 2022) Maker – Merge Risks and Market Impacts – Update 3 (Aug 2022) Maker – Merge Risks and Market Impacts – Update 4 (Sept 2022) Maker – Merge Risks and Market Impacts – Update 5 (Sept 2022) Compound – Proposal: Adjust ETH Interest Rate Model (Aug 2022) Aave – [ARC] Aave ETHPoW Fork Risk Mitigation Plan (Aug 2022)   Impact of FTX Bankruptcy The lack of public information of what projects and companies were affected by the FTX bankruptcy led to high fear, uncertainty, and doubt in the cryptoasset ecosystem. The @Risk-Core-Unit took several proactive steps to counteract potential contagion risks associated with the event, including (i) proposing the offboarding of renBTC-A and (ii) proposing urgent parameter changes of MANA-A, MATIC-A, LINK-A, and YFI-A. More information below.  [USDC-A, USDP-A, GUSD-A] Liquidation parameters & Auctions activation (Nov 2022) MANA-A intermediate parameter change proposal (Nov 2022) [renBTC-A] Proposed Offboarding Parameters & Context (Nov 2022) [Urgent Signal Request] Urgent Recommended Collateral Parameter Changes (Nov 2022)   Dust Higher dust values make vaults less accessible for smaller users but also protect Maker from the risk of vaults being too small to liquidate profitably. It is therefore important to set sufficient dust values, without impeding future growth and adoption. The posts below set out the @Risk-Core-Unit’s analysis on the dust parameter for 2022.  [Signal Request] Adjusting Dust Parameter (2021-4) [Signal Request] Adjusting Dust Parameter - LP Token Vaults (2021-5) (Jan 2022) Discussion: Adjusting Dust Parameter (November 2022)   Maker Improvement Proposals (MIPs)  MIP74: Permissionless Open Market Operation  [Signal Request] Deploy a Trial Permissionless Open Market Operation & Resurrect the Burn (May 2022) MIP74: Permissionless Open Market Operations (May 2022)   MIP39c2-SP35: Modifying Risk Core Unit Mandate - RISK-001  Ratification Poll for Endgame Prelaunch MIP Set - October 10, 2022 MIP39c2-SP35: Modifying Risk Core Unit Mandate - RISK-001 (Latest Proposal Version)  With the Ratification Poll for Endgame Prelaunch MIP Set passing on October 13, 2022, MakerDAO is now in the midst of its transitional phase into the Endgame state. One section of the Endgame Prelaunch MIP Set was MIP39c2-SP35: Modifying Risk Core Unit Mandate - RISK-001, which includes several changes to the @Risk-Core-Unit mandate. The updated mandate makes the @Risk-Core-Unit Facilitator(s) able to unilaterally, and with no additional process, propose non-standard weekly polls and Executive Votes related to:  Decentralized and RWA Collateral management Risk parameter changes for Decentralized and RWA Collateral Other Risk Parameters in the Maker Protocol Decentralized and RWA collateral onboarding Decentralized and RWA Collateral offboarding Other votes and governance actions related to risk, Dai collateral and risk parameters  MKR holders have voted to support MIP39c2-SP35. However, it is worth noting that this MIP was neither created nor proposed by the @Risk-Core-Unit. Nevertheless, the @Risk-Core-Unit will adhere to almost all mandate changes, except for the coverage of RWAs. MKR holders and the Maker community has already been informed of this approach. Hence, RWAs will not be a priority for the @Risk-Core-Unit, and will mostly be covered by the @strat-fin-core-unit. The full difference between the previous and the updated mandate is available here.  MIP84: Activate Protocol-Owned Vault Emulation Another important MIP in the Ratification Poll for Endgame Prelaunch MIP Set is MIP84: Activate Protocol-Owned Vault Emulation. The MIP activates the implementation of a Protocol-Owned Vault (POV), starting with a Protocol-Owned Vault Emulation (POVE) as an initial minimum viable product, manually operated by MKR holders. MIP84 states that the @Risk-Core-Unit is mandated with following the predefined processes as laid out in the MIP. These include: making parameter adjustment proposals, and if necessary, proposing emergency decisions to derisk POVE activity. RISK-001 facilitator actions include but are not limited to:  Stopping the DssKiln from purchasing more collateral Installing a new DssKiln with custom parameters to sell collateral for Dai to wind down the debt of the POVE Partially or fully liquidating the vault using a custom method Modifying any of the parameters that are relevant for derisking the POVE  In 2023, the @Risk-Core-Unit will continue to dedicate the necessary time and effort to follow its mandated responsibilities as laid out in MIP84. However, upcoming changes to the Endgame plan may lead to the implementation of POVE/POV being delayed. The @Risk-Core-Unit will in that case put POVE-related work in the backlog and prioritize other tasks.  Maker Risk Dashboard In May 2021, the Maker Risk Dashboard was introduced – a real-time dashboard with Maker-specific features such as (i) vault type metrics, (ii) collateral asset metrics, and (iii) automated quantitative models. The initial version of the Maker Risk Dashboard acted as a minimum viable product with a clear roadmap in mind. In September 2021, a second version of the Maker Risk Dashboard was deployed – with a new design and several new features, metrics, models, and graphs. All improvements to the Maker Dashboard v2 were documented in the Maker Risk Dashboard forum post and the @Risk-Core-Unit’s “Month in Review” series. In July 2022, the launch of the Maker Risk Dashboard v3 was announced, which represented more than a year’s worth of growth and development from the first iteration. The section below summarizes, in chronological order, key updates to the Maker Risk Dashboard v2 and v3 throughout 2022. content.content: PECU Month in Review: July 2022 July was yet again jam packed! This month saw PECU gather irl to talk about L2 architecture and security assumptions, with some of us staying on to meet other teams at EthCC before heading home to dive back into D3M, Teleport and other smart contract initiatives. Below is a brief summary of the month along with some forward looking descriptions to help delegates in their ongoing prioritization discussions.  Executives   July 06 - Core Unit Distributions, Recognized Delegate Compensation, Keeper Network Stream Setup  July 13 - MOMC Parameter Changes  July 29 - Onboarding Real World Asset Vaults   Forum Posts   Intangible Asset Agreed Modification of Management - security.makerdao. Pending no objection, this will be maintained and updated by PECU Fast Withdrawals and Risk Assumptions   Direct Deposit Module - Aave (aD3M) and Compound (cD3M) With the red team reviews completed and the final contracts handed over to ChainSecurity for audit review at the end of June, the month of July has involved ongoing clarification, feedback and discussion with the auditors to ensure safe contract operation. Changes to the code has been minimal, yet has included minor testing enhancements, better aligned interfaces for integrations, and improved tolerances and rounding calculations. Next steps include:  ChainSecurity to complete a final review of our documented feedback ChainSecurity to incorporate feedback and publish the final report PECU to target an end of August governance vote to put aD3M and cD3M live.  In parallel with the above we continue to review Compound V3 and be a part of their community to follow their deployment of a USDC instance over the following weeks.  L2 Teleport & Fast Withdrawals  Paris Offsite As some may be aware, PECU held its first full-team offsite during the lead-up to EthCC in the outskirts of Paris (optimal focus/temperature & minimal distraction!). We were also lucky enough to have a number of members from Oracles, Growth, Risk, and CES join us for part of the offsite. The objective of this meeting was to bring the teams together for a common understanding of various L2 bridges, message passing services, their designs, features, and inherent implications, risks, and security assumptions. The team will shortly be making available some of the materials presented during the offsite for community awareness. According to the agreement between Maker Growth and GnosisDAO, it is anticipated that the GNO-A vault will only be utilised by the GnosisDAO treasury management team, fully utilizing the available debt ceiling. At the same time, the GNO-A risk parameters need to accommodate the lower liquidity of the GNO token. To reflect these conditions, the recommended risk parameters for GNO-A differ from other Maker collateral. For example, the Dust parameter is set to 100k and the liquidation ratio to 350%. To learn more about the reasoning behind the recommended parameters, refer to the [GNO] Collateral Onboarding Risk Evaluation. The winning poll outcome for onboarding GNO-A was “YES”, on November 24. According to the CSI spreadsheet and PECU, the target executive spell for the GNO Vault Type is December 9, 2022.  Pending Collateral Work  Collateral Status Index  There are currently two collateral types in the implementation phase in the CSI CMON Prefiltered View: (i) Compound D3M, and (ii) GNO. rETH was enabled following the executive vote on November 21. The CSI spreadsheet provides further insight into the assets that are being prioritized and worked on by CMON stakeholders. The report covers Maker’s churn dynamics, looking at how well Maker vault users are retained over time. To learn more about the analysis, conclusion, and possible future research directions, refer to Vault User Research: Survival Analysis.  Monitoring and Mitigation of Economic Risk  Monitoring and Mitigation of Economic Risk - From DeFi tools and processes to on-chain proposals (Nov 24, 2022)  Following @josolnik’s presentation at the ETH Gathering conference in Barcelona (more information below), an in-depth article covering the same topic was posted to the Block Analitica Medium Page. However, gas prices remain far below sustained highs seen in 2021 and early 2022. As a result, a discussion post examining the possibilities of adjusting the dust parameter was published to the forum on November 11, 2022. Read more here. The rETH risk assessment was published on May 20, 2022. The Risk Core Unit is planning to provide updated risk parameter recommendations for the Compound D3M in mid-July. The exact date will depend on the finalized mainnet implementation date. The CSI spreadsheet and the latest CSI Update (June 30, 2022) provides further insight into what assets are being prioritized and worked on by CMON stakeholders. Analysis of the Vault Protection Score Metric The Vault Protection Score is a metric created by the Risk Core Unit which aims to estimate the probability of vault liquidation in times of major market drawdowns. The initial methodology can be found in this post. In June 2022, a new analysis was posted with the objective of evaluating how well the assigned vault protection scores have estimated the probability of vaults being liquidated. The analysis was based on available data from the last 6 months. Based on the result of the analysis, a decision was made to halve the percentages of expected debt exposure that we expect to be liquidated per risk score. The risk scores will now be categorised as follows: (i) 5% for low risk, (ii) 25% for medium risk, and (iii) 50% for high risk. More information available here. Dust Limit Analysis Following a request for an update on Maker protocol dust parameters, @monet-supply provided an new dust limit analysis. A recommendation to not reduce dust limits was the outcome of the analysis. Key reasons include:   Gas cost variability: Network utilization rates can bottom out and rebound quickly. Hence it is not prudent for Maker to rely on current USD denominated gas prices remaining constant.  User experience: Enabling small vaults and then being forced to rapidly reinstate higher dust limits is likely to have a worse impact on user experience than keeping dust levels unchanged. There is also a broad consensus that the costs of transactions on Ethereum L1 is likely to increase over time. Maker’s plans for MCD and D3Ms on Ethereum L2 should provide a more compelling option for small users, once live.  A similar viewpoint by @rema suggests that the critical point is that gas prices can unexpectedly spike in a very short time period ~1h. This is a more relevant metric than historical average gas prices when setting dust limits. In addition, if dust limits were lowered, retail users would likely produce an insignificant amount of DAI debt. Hence, there would be very little advantage for MakerDAO. Whilst at the same time, the protocol and vault users would be exposed to the risk where closing/liquidating certain positions would be unprofitable. Multichain DAI Liquidity Strategy DAI currently has high liquidity on Ethereum L1, with broad integrations to centralized exchanges as well as significant on-chain liquidity sources. Liquidity on external domains, including Ethereum L2s, alternative EVM chains, and non EVM chains, is significantly less deep. On June 27, 2022, a post was published by @monet-supply discussing strategic considerations and ideas for near term actions to address liquidity deficiencies of DAI. Ideas for action include:   Liquidity Incentives: a limited scope of incentives to bootstrap DAI liquidity on external domains to the point where DAI markets become self-sustainable.  Partnerships: Hand in hand with self-funded incentives, Maker can partner with external protocols to support DAI liquidity and integration within their app.  Community Visibility: Independent community members and/or MKR whales don’t face the same governance and custody risks that MakerDAO itself would when deploying assets cross chain. Hence, they could play an important part in improving DAI liquidity across external domains.  Further information available here. The steps were (i) freeze the stETH market, (ii) increase the LT for stETH to 90%, and (iii) pause ETH borrowing. The Risk Core Unit believed that the proposed 90% LT increase for stETH was a particularly risky move. At the time, out of the 200m DAI borrowed on Aave Ethereum v2, 100m DAI was being borrowed by Celsius and collateralized mostly by stETH. This presented a high risk for users borrowing stablecoins collateralized by stETH, especially in light of the fact that Celsius was under stress at the time of the proposal. As a response, to mitigate Aave dependency, the Risk Core Unit suggested that the Aave D3M should be disabled until such time that the Maker community considers it safe to enable it again. The most recent June edition of the MOMC Parameter Changes Proposal suggests that the exposure should remain at 0 (zero) for the time being. Positive feedback was received along with an approval for an Aave grant. On June 10, in a forum post, we requested feedback from the Maker community on scaling and engaging in activities outside of MakerDAO. We believe that any activity Block Analitica engages in outside of the Maker ecosystem should also ideally have tangible benefits for MakerDAO. content.content: This post summarises the tasks, work, and activities of the @Risk-Core-Unit for the month of February. This month’s primary focus is outlined below.  Administrative  RISK-001 Budget Renewal Proposal  MIP40c3-SP92: Modify Risk Core Unit Budget (RISK-001)  MIP40c3-SP92 renews the Risk Core Unit (RISK-001) budget from March 1, 2023, through February 29, 2024. The @Risk-Core-Unit recognizes the current discussions regarding cutting costs. Hence, two voting options have been included: (i) approve existing budget (business as usual) or (ii) approve reduced budget (-10%). It should be noted that the @Risk-Core-Unit believes that the existing budget (business as usual) is still appropriate for two key reasons.  With the current Dai budget, the Risk Core Unit performs one of the most important protocol functions in MakerDAO while being only the 6th largest Core Unit by budget size. The @Risk-Core-Unit’s MKR vesting schedule is relatively low compared to other participants in the DAO. The @Risk-Core-Unit has considered increasing this amount to be more aligned with other Core Units’ MKR per FTE allocations. However, we decided to keep it as it is to be more aligned with the cost-cutting environment at Maker.   Onboarding and Offboarding Risk Facilitator Proposals  MIP41c5-SP14: Facilitator Offboarding - Primoz (RISK-001) MIP41c4-SP41: Risk Facilitator Onboarding (RISK-001)  MIP41c5-SP14 offboards @Primoz as Facilitator of the Risk Core Unit (RISK-001) and MIP41c4-SP41 onboards BA Labs, LLC as a Facilitator, represented by @rema and @monet-supply. Collateral Management  Stakeholder Alignment Following the CES reorganisation, certain collateral management responsibilities have been transferred from the @collateral-core-unit to the @Risk-Core-Unit. The @Risk-Core-Unit is now leading monthly on-chain collateral strategy calls with relevant stakeholders. The first On-Chain Collateral Stakeholder Alignment Meeting was held on February 6, 2023. Meeting points are summarised below.   LSD overview and relation to Endgame: The @Risk-Core-Unit has performed market research into Liquid Staking Derivatives (LSDs) during January and February to better understand the current landscape as it relates to LSDs as Maker collateral and EtherDai (ETHD). @rema gave a high-level overview of the results. In summary, no additional staking derivative is currently suitable as Maker collateral. However, it is worth following the developments of LSDs as the industry is still in its infancy. In addition, more work needs to be done to understand the most optimal design and strategy for MakerDAO’s own staking product – EtherDai (ETHD).  Existing low liquidity collateral assets and their potential for SubDAOs: During the meeting, GNO, LINK, MATIC, and YFI were identified as collateral types that will likely fall under the “Strategic Collateral Asset Type” or the “Transitory Collateral Asset Type” categorisation in the Decentralized Scope Framework. Based on the latest Decentralized Scope Framework language, these assets will not be considered strategic, and will therefore likely fall under the “Transitory Collateral Asset Type” category. Hence, a potential migration plan to designated SubDAOs will be needed for these assets in the future.  rETH Maker campaign to stimulate usage and increase demand: The MOMC proposed a reduction of the RETH-A stability fee to 0.5% for at least 3 months to boost demand and usage. It was suggested that a potential marketing campaign may be appropriate to inform users of this initiative.  Initial Margin Requirements: @monet-supply initiated a discussion regarding the potential benefits of implementing initial margin requirements to Maker vaults (i.e. requirements for opening a vault, minting DAI, or removing collateral). Adding separate initial margin requirements to Maker vaults may improve protocol safety and competitiveness while having a negligible impact on vault user experience. More discussion is needed from relevant stakeholders. A more in-depth explanation of the idea may be posted to the forum to invite further discussion.  MIP92: Yearn Maker Vault: The ratification poll for MIP92 (Onboard PSM USDC to Yearn to earn Yield) passed in January 2023. The topic was therefore brought up for discussion to identify possible opportunities at Yearn. It is believed that the largest requirement is technical and development work. From the @Risk-Core-Unit’s perspective, an analysis can be made on existing Yearn strategies, examining financial risk profiles and external DeFi exposures.   Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework During the Pregame phase of the ongoing MakerDAO Endgame plan, the @Risk-Core-Unit will help bootstrap the Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework by providing relevant feedback on its contents, language, and structure. To increase operational transparency, the @Risk-Core-Unit will from now on report this work on a monthly basis through the Risk Core Unit Month in Review series. Endgame During Pregame, the @Risk-Core-Unit will have other responsibilities and priorities in addition to the work on the Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework. Block Analitica now has a Medium page. The first post, written by @josolnik, discusses the concept of Computer-Aided Governance and how the @Risk-Core-Unit aims to support better-informed decisions by using the Maker Risk Dashboard as guidance. The article is available here. During the weekend of January 21 to January 23, the cryptoasset ecosystem experienced a significant, sudden market downtrend. The surplus auction (FLAP) inefficiency led to the event being termed “Flappy Friday”. The incident was explained in detail by @Primoz on January 23. The analysis is available here. The analysis was used to help form an urgent signal request to stop MKR burning. The changes were proposed to temporarily prevent surplus auctions until the auction mechanisms can be improved. An out-of-schedule executive proposal was passed on January 24 and subsequently executed on January 26. The changes were: (i) disable the existing System Surplus Buffer lerp function, and (ii) set the System Surplus Buffer parameter to 250 million DAI. Two Risk Core Unit members, @Primoz and @monet-supply, are part of the MakerDAO Open Market Committee. Several factors changed following the market crash in January. (i) DeFi lending rates dropped off considerably, (ii) funding rates on centralised exchanges are holding close to 2-year lows, and (iii) the DAI supply through the USDC-PSM has increased significantly, reaching a stablecoin backing ratio of 62%. The Open Market Committee reacted by proposing several changes, including (i) decreasing the stability fee for multiple vault types, (ii) decreasing the AAVE-D3M target borrow rate, and (iii) decreasing the maximum debt ceiling of GUNIV3DAIUSDC1-A while increasing the debt ceiling, target available debt and decreasing the stability fee for GUNIV3DAIUSDC2-A. The changes may help stimulate more DAI minting with other collateral types besides stablecoins. However, the anticipated effect on annualized revenue is negative 6.7 million DAI. The proposed changes are currently included in an on-chain poll, and if passed, will be included in an executive vote on February 4, 2022. Several updates and improvements to the MakerDAO Risk Dashboard were undertaken, such as (i) implementing a Compound D3M Model, (ii) site reliability improvements, and (iii) moving to a new data API from the Data Insights Core Unit (DICU). More information about these updates is set out below. A new budget modification proposal, MIP40c3-SP56, was posted to the forum on January 12. In the short to medium term, the @Risk-Core-Unit plans to increase the headcount from 8 to 11 full-time equivalent (FTE) contributors. Makerburn has been financed by a grant program led by the Risk Core Unit since June 2021. We are now joining forces with Makerburn on a team level. In March, we posted a product discussion on a Maker owned Fuse Pool and a Maker Fuse D3M. We are currently gathering feedback from the community. A Signal Request on this topic will soon be posted. Recently in an on-chain vote, the community decided to finalize the offboarding of TUSD via liquidations. As a follow-up, the Risk Core Unit posted recommended offboarding parameters for TUSD-A. The Executive Vote planned for Friday, April 15th, 2022 will enact these changes and enable liquidations for TUSD-A. In March, MakerDAO’s first Curve LP token collateral, CRVV1ETHSTETH-A, was onboarded. The Risk Core Unit proposed some updated parameter recommendations before its release to mainnet. Changes included:  decreasing the debt ceiling by 2 million from 5 million to 3 million; decreasing the stability fee by 1% from 4.5% to 3.5%; increasing the dust by 15,000 from 10,000 to 25,000.  Note that the MakerDAO Open Market Committee (MOMC) has since then assessed the performance of CRVV1ETHSTETH-A and has recommended decreasing the stability fee by 1.25% from 3.5% to 2.25%. More information on this below. @Primoz and @rema posted their feedback on an informal poll focusing on ways to increase the competitiveness of ETH & stETH collateral. Primoz highlighted the risk factors of using aETH as collateral. He also raised several key points to consider if Maker decides to add other wstETH collateral types. Rema analysed the risks, and assessed the potential demand, for additional wstETH and aETH vault types. In summary, it is believed that wstETH-B will generate relatively low demand, while wstETH-C has a higher potential to gain traction. The added risks of an aETH vault type are likely to outweigh the potential benefits to MakerDAO. In the Governance and Risk #184 meeting on March 31, 2022, the Risk Core Unit further discussed the topic of ETH staking derivatives. Questions included:  What are the current market trends for stETH usage in DeFi? What are actions that Maker should consider? What effect will rising ETH/stETH yields have on Stability Fees? How can Maker become a more attractive protocol for stETH owners?  Potential collateral alternatives were discussed. These included (i) wstETH-C, (ii) leveraged stETH as collateral, and (iii) support for other staking derivatives, such as rETH (Rocket Pool). Updates and improvements to the MakerDAO Risk Dashboard, including an Auction Kick Simulation and scaling out D3M monitoring tools, were undertaken. More details follow below. content.content: PECU Month in Review: May 2022 May was a very packed month - from panel discussions at Permissionless Miami (shoutout Sam!), to full team code reviews, podcasts (shoutout Bartek!), audit sessions, smart contract development along with various architectural research endeavours, Protocol Engineering was kept pretty busy. Meanwhile various DeFi protocols also kept us on edge (keepers…shoutout Mooney!) as UST failed to hold peg. The following is a summary of the month’s work:  Executives During May we updated our internal spell writing processes and have since been deploying executives on Wednesday to allow for better cross-team coordination, fact checking and reviews. The following executives were released during May:   May 25 - Raise the ESM Minimum Threshold, MKR Vesting, Adjust the lid Parameter on the Rate-limited Flapper  May 18 Foundational L2 Work, Authorize New Flash Mint Module, MKR Vesting  May 11 - Recognized Delegate Payments, Lowering WBTC Stability Fees, and Onboarding wstETH-B   Forum Posts  Ratified MIP69 L2-to-L1 Fast Withdrawals Proposed a PoC, DssKiln - a permissionless token purchasing tool Included DssCure Technical Enhancement in the 18th May Executive Included Flash Mint Module update in the 18th May Executive Implemented an improved Governance Cadence Improvement Process    Direct Deposit Module Work  PECU were involved in extensive line-by-line internal code reviews. Which involved pool, plan and hub contracts alongside numerous stateful and stateless fuzzing tests. Can not be understated how much diligence and team review effort went into this work. Reviews for both the underlying D3M infrastructure and the Compound contracts commenced in May and will be wrapping up in June for audit completion in mid-July.   Cross-team work We also saw increased cross-team participation this month, namely:  Working with the Deco team to help fuzz testing with Echidna. Next steps will be to review their formal proof documentation before deployment. Held a discussion with the StarkWare company and the StarkNet CU on the topic of gradual decentralization Provided CES interview support Provided support to Nexo for getting their infrastructure setup and ready in the event that they pursue Institutional Vaults. Met with the Paradigm research team to explore TWAMM solutions in light of recent DssKiln discussions. Integrated reccommendations from DAI Foundation to include Copyright guidance  Provided technical implementation support to the Makershire Hathaway initiative Participation in Community Decentralized Voter Committee discussions   Smart Contract work As usual, our weekly planning sessions saw a substantial push across a variety of value add feature functionality, including:  Enhancements to DssExecLib to improve our testfail coverage Improvement PRs to slither static analysis tooling for improved test functionality Improved timestamp creation and validation via a time PR  Improved DssExecLib documentation for RWAs  Made final improvements to the chainlog  Documented integration tests as part of emergency shutdown scenarios. Planning completion in June leading to improvements in dss-simulation-scripts  Integration tests to optimize poking the medianizer Added DssFlash legacy contract into Dune Analytics for monitoring as we deployed a new Flash module Optimised GemJoin9 to take into consideration check-effect-interaction patterns for use in PAXG Partly completed reviews of dss-charter including; join, exit and move. Code and audits is complete, further team review will continue pending market appetite to adopt Completed Univ2-lp-oracle and Univ3-lp-oracle  Added WSTETH-B ilk to the megapoker  Updated WSTETH callee contract to support a complex univ3 path Added AuctionDemoKeeper to support complex univ3 paths for curve LP tokens Updated the OSM mom with a PR that sets the debt ceiling to 0 and removing the autoline DssProxyRegistry was deployed on several production networks Updated authorization checks in Goerli    L2 As per our Stakeholder Alignment Meetings, the bulk of the work to deploy L2 → L1 fast withdrawals is now complete and is only awaiting a final team review before being ready for deployment in early July. This month’s L2 specific focus has included:  Codebase renaming of wormhole to teleport Wrote and deployed keepers and coordinated ownership with TechOps Created Forta test suite for L2 monitoring Worked with Gelato to integrate the trusted relay Provided SDK support for Socket and Li.Finance teams to integrate Fast Withdrawals into their frontends Helped StarkWare team to align DAI StarkGate bridge architecture to our other bridges Forward looking research of the End contract and its behaviour in the event of L2 emergency shutdown Review of Cure implementation and its interaction with the End Research into Vat optimization for L2 domains Development of DssBridge as means to scale L2 adoption Commenced research into LayerZero and Axelar cross-chain communication services   Infrastructure With OpenEthereum riding into the sunset, many of us have been upgrading our node testing infrastructure to Erigon nodes for Goerli and Mainnet, which has taken some time but is now complete.  Safety Subteam Work  Worked with Certora to provide proofs for Layer2 contracts Documented a Curve LP Oracle postmortem - awaiting confirmation that there are no other parties at risk before publishing Added mathematical & strong induction sections to FV course for release in June Created documentation explaining the relationship between sequences, and recurrence relations to state transition systems - which help us create tooling to ensure smart contracts do what we expect. Created syntax highlight support and ported mcd-spec to Athena allowing for proof tests Final stages of releasing the symbolic EVM with foundry integration   June Priorities Spotlight Aside from supporting a number of planned collateral on/off-boardings, minor technical upgrades (ClipperCallees, AuctionDemoKeepers, etc), and the usual executive spells, our primary focus is on:  D3M final reviews and providing audit support Teleport final reviews to deploy to mainnet DssCharter (previously deprioritised) so Institutions can adopt when ready

content.content: PECU Month in Review: March 2022  Executive Votes:   March 4 - Core Unit Budget Distributions, Recognized Delegate Compensation, MOMC Parameter Changes  March 9 - Mitigate Post-Shutdown Flash Loan Vulnerability  March 11 - Curve stETH-ETH Onboarding, Rate Limited Flapper, Immunefi Bug Bounty Payouts  March 25 - Authorizing the ESM on DssFlash and Adding Support for TUSD Implementation   Smart Contract Development   Auction Demo Keeper deployment to support TUSD Offboarding Identified that TUSD implementation was changed and subsequently informed the community Redeployed the OmegaPoker to support curve LP tokens and updated new megapoker tests  Deployed Clipper callee for curve LP token integration with UniSwapV3 PE Team completed a code walk-through and review of the Deco protocol, which was subsequently handed over to auditors for review Development of the Flash Killer Keeper to check if  the kill() function is available and if so, ensure that flash mints are disabled if emergency shutdown is triggered Prototyped DssKiln with a description allowing the burning of DAI over time against a defined AMM contract Began architectural discussions to ensure that DssGate would be extensible to other DAO-wide initiatives as this was inherited and specific to Deco   Forum Posts   Protocol Engineering Core Unit Workstreams proposal and structure Protocol Engineering Core Unit Budget Proposal  MIP69: L2 to L1 Fast Withdrawals Proposal   Request to Poll for Maker Wormhole Deployment and Associated Risk Parameters StarkNet Dai Technical Bridge Risk Assessment  Notification of FlashThaw issue and remedy Flash Loan Debt Manipulation During Emergency Shutdown vulnerability explanation  Out of plan Executive added to prevent malicious activation of the DssFlash module after being disabled by the FlashKiller contract Ongoing work to deprecate the old Changelog    Events  Protocol Engineering joined SF, SES and SH CUs at Harvard Blockchain Week. We have sourced a number of graduates and are reviewing candidates.   The Month Ahead  Protocol Engineering is in the final stages of being ready to deploy Fast Withdrawals on Optimism and Arbitrum. Outstanding work is limited to receiving final audit responses on critical modules, finalising formal verification specs, and putting in place the required bridge monitoring and alerting. Similarly, we are approaching completion on the Compound D3M, which will put in place a modular architecture facilitating reuse and scalability. In the same spirit of scalability, DssGate will enable MakerDAO to support debt ceiling limited initiatives such as the Deco Protocol and other “sand-box-like” initiatives. Protocol Engineering is also actively following current RWA discussions and is at the ready to help CES with any onboarding oversight required. We do not however expect that these discussions, if ratified, will impact or alter long-tail work such as Institutional Vaults, D3Ms or ongoing MCD on L2 development, as these initiatives entail different non-competing resources - I am happy to elaborate on this further if requested.
